verses.text: There shall no evil happen unto him that feareth the Lord; But in temptation even again he will deliver him.
A wise man hateth not the law; But he that is a hypocrite therein \add is\add* as a ship in a storm.
A man of understanding trusteth in the law; And the law \add is\add* faithful unto him, as an oracle.
Prepare what to say, and so thou shalt be heard: \add And\add* bind up instruction, and then make answer.
The heart of the foolish \add is like\add* a cartwheel; And his thoughts \add are\add* like a rolling axletree.
A stallion horse \add is\add* as a mocking friend, He neigheth under every one that sitteth upon \add him\add*.
Why doth one day excel another, When as all the light of \add every\add* day in the year \add is\add* of the sun?
By the knowledge of the Lord they were distinguished: And he altered seasons and feasts.
\add Some\add* of them hath he made high days, and hallowed \add them\add*, And \add some\add* of them hath he made ordinary days.
And all men \add are\add* from the ground, And Adam was created of earth.
In much knowledge the Lord hath divided them, And made their ways diverse.

\add Some\add* of them hath he blessed and exalted, And \add some\add* of them hath he sanctified, and set near himself: \add But some\add* of them hath he cursed and brought low, And turned out of their places.
As the clay \add is\add* in the potterâ€™s hand, To fashion it at his pleasure: So man \add is\add* in the hand of him that made him, To render to them as liketh him best.
Good \add is set\add* against evil, And life against death: So \add is\add* the godly against the sinner, And the sinner against the godly.
So look upon all the works of the most High; \add And there are\add* two \add and\add* two, one against another.
I awaked up last \add of all\add*, As one that gathereth after the grapegatherers: By the blessing of the Lord I profited, And filled \add my\add* winepress like a gatherer of grapes.
Consider that I laboured not for myself only, But for all them that seek learning.
Hear me, O \add ye\add* great men of the people, And hearken with your ears, ye rulers of the congregation.

Give not \add thy\add* son and wife, \add thy\add* brother and friend, power over thee while thou livest, And give not thy goods to another: Lest it repent thee, and thou intreat for the same \add again\add*.
As long as thou livest and hast breath in thee, Give not thyself over to any.
For better it is that \add thy\add* children should seek to thee, Than that thou shouldest stand to their courtesy.
In all thy works keep to thyself the pre-eminence; Leave not a stain in thine honour.
At the time when thou shalt end thy days, And finish \add thy\add* life, distribute \add thine\add* inheritance.
Fodder, a wand, and burdens, \add are\add* for the ass; \add And\add* bread, correction, and work, for a servant.
If thou set thy servant to labour, thou shalt find rest: \add But\add* if thou let him go idle, he shall seek liberty.
A yoke and a collar do bow the neck: So \add are\add* tortures and torments for an evil servant.
Send him to labour, that he be not idle; For idleness teacheth much evil.
Set \add him\add* to work, as is fit for him: If he be not obedient, put on more heavy fetters.
But be not excessive toward any; And without discretion do nothing.
If thou have a servant, let him be unto thee as thyself, Because thou hast bought him with a price.

If thou have a servant, entreat him as a brother: For thou hast need of him, as \add of\add* thine own soul: If thou entreat him evil, and he run from \add thee\add*, Which way wilt thou \add go to\add* seek him?
